Diagnosis .
Cybaeus aspenicolens
is grouped with
C. blasbes
and
C. coylei
spec. nov. in the informal
aspenicolens
subgroup. Distinguishing the
aspenicolens
and
fraxineus
subgroups is discussed in the
aspenicolens
species group diagnosis. Males of
C. aspenicolens
and
C. blasbes
are distinguished from males of
C. coylei
spec. nov. by the proximal arm of the tegular apophysis being clearly visible in ventral view ( Figs 3 , 6 ) and the patellar apophysis with two dozen or fewer large, conspicuous peg setae retrolaterally, 15 or fewer small peg setae dorsally, and retrolateral margin slightly concave distal to retrolateral peg setae group ( Figs 2 , 5 , 11–12 ) in
C. aspenicolens
and
C. blasbes versus
proximal arm deflected dorsally and mostly hidden in ventral view ( Fig. 9 ) and the patellar apophysis with 30 or more conspicuous peg setae retrolaterally, about two dozen small peg setae dorsally, and retrolateral margin smoothly rounded distal to retrolateral peg setae group ( Figs 8 , 13 ) in
C. coylei
spec. nov.

Males of
C. aspenicolens
and
C. blasbes
are differentiated by the number and morphology of the patellar apophysis peg setae and, less noticeably, by the morphology of the tips of the proximal arm of the tegular apophysis and the patellar apophysis. The patellar apophysis in male
C. aspenicolens
has two dozen large retrolateral peg setae and fewer than ten (usually four to seven) very small dorsal peg setae ( Figs 2 , 11 ) versus no more than 20 large retrolateral peg setae and usually at least 12 short but stout dorsal peg setae ( Figs 5 , 12 ) in
C. blasbes
. The tip of the proximal arm of the tegular apophysis is relatively short and only slightly twisted ( Figs 3–4 ) in
C. aspenicolens versus
somewhat longer and more strongly twisted ( Figs 6–7 ) in
C. blasbes
. Finally, the tip of the patellar apophysis is relatively short and blunt ( Figs 2 , 11 ) in
C. aspenicolens versus
blunt but relatively elongated ( Figs 5 , 12 ) in
C. blasbes
.

Females of
C. aspenicolens
and
C. blasbes
are characterized by an at least slightly sclerotized epigynum and a pronounced anterior ridge on the epigynal depression ( Figs 16, 18 ) versus an unsclerotized epigynum and no anterior ridge in
C. coylei
spec. nov. ( Fig. 14 ).

Females of
C. aspenicolens
can be distinguished from those of
C. blasbes
by the presence of a pair of small, sclerotized longitudinal flaps covering the atrial openings ( Fig. 16 ) and less reliably by the copulatory ducts frequently broadly joined along midline of vulva ( Figs 17 , 21 ) in
C. aspenicolens versus
atrial openings sclerotized but exposed and not covered by longitudinal flaps ( Fig. 18 ) and vulval ducts usually not joined medially ( Figs 19 , 23–24 ) in
C. blasbes
.
Description . Ventral macrosetae on tibia I usually 2–1p–2–1p–2.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 5–7.
Cybaeus blasbes
, males, left palpus (5 from near Fish Camp, California. 6–7 from Shaver Lake, California). 5 patella and tibia, dorsal; 6 genital bulb, ventral; 7 genital bulb, retrolateral. PA—proximal arm of tegular apophysis.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution and natural history . Western slopes of the Sierra Nevada in and around western Yosemite National Park ( Fig 41 ). Type series specimens were collected from small, irregular webs under rotting logs and other objects on a hillside at about 6000’. Males have been collected in September.
